Section 1 M:  Man      W:  Woman W:   Good afternoon, and welcome to AngloAir.  Where are you flying to today? M:   Hi.  I’m flying to Paris today. After that, I’m going to Munich, but by train, and then flying back to London. W:   Sounds interesting.  It’s Mr…? M:   Wickens, David Wickens. W:   Ok, well, let’s get you checked in, then, Mr. Wickens, for Paris.  Do you have your ticket and passport? M:   Yes, somewhere here… yes, here they are.  Ticket… and passport. W:   Ok, let’s see, economy class, leaving from City Airport, London, to Paris, leaving 1:30, arriving 3 pm local time, with the one hour time difference.  Do you have a seat preference? M:   Well, it’s a short flight, but I do prefer a window seat, if one’s available. W:   Yes, I think there are a couple left, give me a second here…, yes, here we are.   We have seat 7A or 16A available. M:   The front of the plane, please, so, the first one. W:   No problem, Mr. Wickens.  And are you a Frequent-Flyer member. It’s not noted here on your booking…. M:   Yes, I’ve been a member for years - I guess I forgot to give them my number when I made the booking.  It’s 468319. W:   468319, correct? M:   Yes, that’s it.   You now have some time to read questions 6 to 10. Now listen carefully and answer questions 6 -10. W:   Now, I see your passport is about to expire. You only have 7 months left. M: Yes – I’ve already applied for a new one. Is it OK to fly with today? W: Sure – you need to have at least 6 months remaining to fly. Right, then.  Now, how many bags do you have to check in? M:   Well, I will check in just this suitcase, but I have a carry-on briefcase, plus my laptop, but I’ll keep them both with me. W:   Right, no problem, just put your bag here.  How about your carry-on bags?  The weight limit for those is 7 kilograms, in total.  And for your suitcase, it’s 20 kilograms on these smaller flights. Let’s weigh your carry-on bags. Hmm… a total of just under 30 kilograms. But we’ll just let everything through today, Mr. Wickens.  The flight’s not full, so should be alright. M:   Ok, thank you for that.  What’s the boarding time for this flight? W:  Well, it’s a 1:30 departure, and it’s noon now, and you have to be at the Gate 20 minutes before departure for boarding, so just after 1, 1:10 to be exact.  Try to be there earlier, though, if you can. Often, the flight can leave a little earlier, that is, if everyone’s on board. M:  Ok, no problem. W:  Now, I think that’s just about everything.  I hope you have a good flight, and, just for the future, a couple of suggestions.  Do you usually get a ticket, or have you used our E-Ticket service? M:  Yes, of course, I normally get an E-Ticket, but, my secretary was away, so I just bought an ordinary ticket.  W:  Oh, ok. And, of course, on our Atlantic flights, do you ever use our E-Check-in?  You can check in electronically.  M:   Yes, I always do that, but you don’t have that service here for the Paris flight. W:   Correct, that’s coming soon.  And, finally, do you normally stay at the same hotel here in London? M:   Yes, usually, I do.  Why? W:   Well, I suggest that you get one of our brochures about all of our services, including accommodation, check-in facilities, range of flight services and transportation options.  If you just ask at our Service Counter - it’s just past the Check-In facilities - I think you’ll be interested in some of the things we offer. M:   Ok. That sounds great, I appreciate your advice.  And thanks for your help…
